title: Database Security
learning_objectives: Understand the Database Security concept in SQL

definition.concept_explanation: Database Security is an important SQL concept for working with databases.

examples.title: SQL Example 1
examples.sql: SELECT D.floor, AVG (D.budget) FROM Dept D GROUP BY D.tloor HAVING COUNT (*) > 2 6. SELECT D.tloor, AVG (D.budget) FROM Dept D GROUP BY D.floor ORDER BY D.floor Exercise 15.4 You are given the following information: Executives has attributes ename, title, dname, COUNT (*) > 2 6. SELECT D.tloor, AVG (D.budget) FROM Dept D GROUP BY D.floor ORDER BY D.floor Exercise 15.4 You are given the following information: Executives has attributes ename, title, dname, and address;

common_mistakes.title: Syntax error
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: Typo in SQL keyword. The correct keyword is FROM, not FORM.

common_mistakes.title: Missing semicolon
common_mistakes.error_message: Some databases require semicolons to end statements
common_mistakes.why_it_happens: While some SQL implementations are lenient, it's best practice to end statements with semicolons.
common_mistakes.key_takeaway: Always end SQL statements with a semicolon
